An outline for a Lecture for Public Health Institute.
Prophylaxis of Yellow Fever.
A) Points to Emphasize:
(1) State the Mechanism of Conveyance.

(2) Give the two methods of prophylaxis: Viz:--
(a) Control of the human host,
(b) Control of the insect host.

(3) Describe the first in sufficient detail to understand what is
done--giving principles--physical and psychical on which it rests, so
that their application can be understood.
(4) Compare their applicability of (a) & of (b) above and give the indications for each one.

(5) Give so much of the life history of Aedes (Stegomyia) calopus as
is necessary to understand the detail methods of control of the insect
host.

(6) Describe control of insect host--going into some detail--giving
special difficulties and special methods.
(7) Vaccination as adjuvant to campaign.

(8) Spontaneous elimination of yellow fever by failure of the human
host.
B) Mistakes to Avoid.

Attempting to cover the subject too closely in the time allowance
of one lecture.

Malaria Control.
A. Points to Emphasize:
1) State the mechanism of conveyance of malarial in nature.

11) State the general principle of its control, viz: to prevent the
access of infective Anopheles mosquitoes to uninfected men.

The methods for carrying this out are
(a) Get rid of Anopheles mosquitoes:
(b) Prevent the infection of Anopheles mosquitoes:
(c) Prevent access of Anopheles mosquitoes to men--of infective
mosquitoes to well men and of uninfected mosquitoes to infected men.

A fourth method may be added (d)
(d) So to administer quinine to men as to immunize them against
malarial fever even when bitten by infective Anopheles.

This last is basically palliative only and except as it may lead
to other measures is not to be commended for permanent control, save
under exceptional conditions.
Then should follow a developement of the methods enumerated, viz:

Under a/ get rid of Anopheles mosquitoes:
by (1) preventing production--by control of their breeding places
by (2) hand killing those found in residences, with, it may be, oc-
casional fumigation in screened houses.
by (3) removal of shelters of Anopheles near residences.

Under b/ Preventing the infection of Anopheles
by (1) freeing all infected men (“carriers”) in the community of
malarial parasites:
by (2) keeping such carriers behind screens and mosquito bars at
night--the feeding time of Anopheles.

" c/ Prevent access of Anopheles to men by
(1) keeping men behind screens and mosquito bars at night.
" d/ The use of quinine to immunize against malarial attacks.

These subdivisions should be developed to such extent as the
time allows when they are enunciated, laying stress on such as are
of 2 (most general applicability and) 1 (greatest value.)

applicability.
2

In my opinion a/ (1) stands first in this combination, b/ (1)
next and then c/ (1).

A brief statement of results and costs should be given for the
use of the different methods and, as far as may be, the indications
for the use of each set forth.
B) Points to Avoid.

I can think of none, except attempting to cover the subject too
much in detail and thus not keeping the proper proportion between its
divisions. It is a large subject for one lecture.

C) The two most important books now available on this subject:
In my judgement these are:--
1/ The Prevention of Malaria--by Ronald Ross--and
2/ The First Vol. of “The Mosquitoes of North America”-- Howard:
Dyar and Knab.

The first is an old book--published in 1910, I believe, but I
know of none so good.

The second is not new. I got it in the beginning of 1914--and
much has been added to our knowledge of the Anopheles of the U. S.
since that time. Yet it is a most excellent book.

I would say that I have not been able to do any systematic read-
ing on this subject since the spring of 1917, at which time I took
charge of the malaria sanitation of the Extra-Cantonment Zones, and,
it may be, there are better newer books which I have not seen.
